column1: "content": "A qualitative study of views and experiences of\nwomen and health care professionals about free maternal vaccinations administered at community pharmacies.Vaccines2020
column7: M. Delivering prenatal pertussis vaccine through maternity services in\nEngland: What is the impact on vaccine coverage? Vaccine 2020
column16: C.C. Increasing uptake of maternal\npertussis vaccinations through funded administration in community pharmacies. Vaccines 2022

column36: attitudes and learning needs regarding antenatal vaccination. Midwifery 2018

column3: 557 11 of 15\nto women (76.4%) was protection of their infant from illness ( p < 0.001
column4: CV 0.336 for\nassociation with acceptance) [74]. Since the completion of our data synthesis
column5: one scoping\nreview and one qualitative systematic review on related aspects of maternal immunization\nhighlighted women\u2019s need for clear information
column7: in a meaningful way that addresses identified barriers [75
column10: and HCPs have to collectively educate pregnant women about the\neffectiveness and safety of maternal vaccines and encourage vaccination when the benefits\noutweigh the risks [77]. Consistent and evidence-enabled recommendations from HCPs
column11: \nwith mindfulness of the sociodemographic and cultural background of pregnant women
column12:
would foster the acceptance of vaccination in pregnancy as an essential component of
antenatal care. Global experience and lessons learned from the rollout of the COVID-19
vaccination during the antenatal period provided valuable insights that can inform current
and future approaches to optimise maternal vaccination strategies [30
column13: 78].\n5. Limitations\nThomson\u2019s 5A taxonomy is based on factors supported by evidential statements
column14: and\nwe conducted this scoping review in a similar manner
column15: examining each study for factors\ninfluencing or related to the maternal vaccine coverage landscape in Ireland. However
column16: \ndue to the limited number of quantitative studies and study designs
column18: while often supported by qualitative findings
column19: do not represent statistical\nassociations with vaccine uptake. Additionally
column21: no critical\nappraisal of the literature was conducted to determine the rigour and validity of the\nfindings
column22: and no risk-of-bias analysis and quality of evidence assessments were performed\nas part of this scoping review. Therefore
column23: care is recommended when deciding which factors\nto target in future intervention designs to optimise the antenatal vaccination rates as an\nintegral part of a life-course preventative approach [26
column27: illuminates the intricate web of factors that\nshape maternal vaccination uptake in Ireland. From knowledge gaps to healthcare provider\nperspectives
column30:
the narrative encompasses a
diverse range of determinants that are likely responsible for the low maternal vaccination
rates observed. Potential effective strategies for improving antenatal vaccination uptake are
consistent and sustained recommendations by HCPs
column31: including reminders in antenatal care\npacks and targeted public awareness campaigns
column32: along with optimal utilization of social\nmedia. By addressing the identified barriers and harnessing facilitators
column33: a roadmap can be\ncharted towards a landscape where maternal vaccination is embraced as a critical part of a\nlife-course immunization strategy
column34:
fostering the well-being of both mothers and infants. It
is paramount to recognize that national immunization programmes need realignment and
redesign with inter-stakeholder and inter-agency participation to ensure comprehensive
protection for individuals across the lifespan. By adopting a life-course approach to immu-
nization
column35: with maternal vaccination as the pivotal central point
column36:
vaccination programmes
could close immunity gaps at various life stages.

Abstract: Background: Maternal vaccination is a critical primary preventive approach and an
integral part of life-course immunization strategy
column38: influencing the infection-associated morbidity\nand mortality in pregnant women
column40: and young infants. Despite clear guidelines for\nthe administration of vaccines against tetanus
column45: maternal vaccination rates remain suboptimal in Ireland as per\nthe National Immunisation Office of the Health Service Executive (HSE).Aim: This review\nexplores the prevailing status
column47: and maternal immunization-specific vaccine hesi-\ntancy in Ireland.Method: A scoping review was conducted
column49:
including the Irish health research repository Lenus. The search strategy utilised a Population–
Concept–Context framework (pregnant women—vaccine uptake/hesitancy—Ireland). Key
factors identified and categorised according to the 5A framework: access
column54: and 12 eligible studies\nwere included for review. Influencing factors were identified in each of the 5A dimensions
column55:
with
the majority relating to acceptance and awareness. Positively associated factors included health-
care provider (HCP) recommendation and knowledge of vaccine safety . Potential antenatal
barriers were maternal lack of knowledge of vaccine-preventable illness severity
column57: \nand vaccine safety concerns. A pregnant woman\u2019s primary motivation for antenatal immuniza-\ntion was protection of her infant; however
column58: the reluctance of HCPs to prescribe all recommended\nantenatal vaccines
column59: inadequate immunization-specific discussion during antenatal consultations
column60:
and suboptimal knowledge of pregnancy-specific vaccine safety hampered potential positive
influences. The Irish national immunization policy was a facilitator of affordability . Activation
can be achieved through public health awareness campaigns and interdisciplinary promotion
of maternal vaccination uptake.Conclusions: Maternal vaccination uptake in Ireland remains
suboptimal
column64: and highlighting vaccine safety in pregnancy would be required to meet\nthe life-course immunization goals recommended by WHO."

Abstract: Background: Maternal vaccination is a critical primary preventive approach and an
integral part of life-course immunization strategy
column64: influencing the infection-associated morbidity\nand mortality in pregnant women
column66: and young infants. Despite clear guidelines for\nthe administration of vaccines against tetanus
column71: maternal vaccination rates remain suboptimal in Ireland as per\nthe National Immunisation Office of the Health Service Executive (HSE).Aim: This review\nexplores the prevailing status
column73: and maternal immunization-specific vaccine hesi-\ntancy in Ireland.Method: A scoping review was conducted
column75:
including the Irish health research repository Lenus. The search strategy utilised a Population–
Concept–Context framework (pregnant women—vaccine uptake/hesitancy—Ireland). Key
factors identified and categorised according to the 5A framework: access
column80: and 12 eligible studies\nwere included for review. Influencing factors were identified in each of the 5A dimensions
column81:
with
the majority relating to acceptance and awareness. Positively associated factors included health-
care provider (HCP) recommendation and knowledge of vaccine safety . Potential antenatal
barriers were maternal lack of knowledge of vaccine-preventable illness severity
column83: \nand vaccine safety concerns. A pregnant woman’s primary motivation for antenatal immuniza-\ntion was protection of her infant; however
column84: the reluctance of HCPs to prescribe all recommended\nantenatal vaccines

and suboptimal knowledge of pregnancy-specific vaccine safety hampered potential positive

column90: and highlighting vaccine safety in pregnancy would be required to meet\nthe life-course immunization goals recommended by WHO. By adopting a life-course immu-\nnization approach for healthy living

column130:
557 2 of 15
Keywords: maternal vaccination; maternal immunization; life-course immunization; scoping
review; vaccine hesitancy; antenatal care; pregnancy
1. Introduction
Almost half of all child deaths occur in the first month of life [1]
column131: and 45% of under-five\nmortality is from infectious diseases [2]. For the mother–infant dyad
column132: pregnancy and early\ninfancy are vulnerable windows for infection [3]. The pregnant mother’s physiology and\nimmunology undergo gestation-specific changes
column133: increasing the risk of severe disease [4
column135: the foetus develops an independent immune system
column136: reaching relative maturity around\nthree months after birth
column137: making newborn infants highly susceptible to infection [6
column139: the maternal immune system provides passive protection to\nthe foetus and newborn via the transfer of antibodies and antimicrobial proteins via placental\ncirculation
column140: and subsequently through colostrum and breast milk [8]. Colostrum is regarded as\n‘nature’s first vaccine’
column141: enriched with IgA antibodies and a multitude of bioactive properties [1
column142:
2].
Preterm infants pose additional challenges as they lack the opportunity for the trans-placental
antibody (IgG) transfer that occurs in the last trimester [1]. Boosting immunity through maternal
vaccination is a key strategy in protecting pregnant women and their infants against infectious
diseases and reducing their severity
column143:
and is thus unique in providingtransgenerational primary
preventionthrough a single intervention [1].
Vaccination in pregnancy confers valuable passive protection to the newborn. His-
torically
column144: the only vaccination offered in pregnancy globally was against neonatal tetanus\n(tetanus toxoid
column145: TT) [ 3]. While the prevalence of neonatal tetanus has dramatically de-\ncreased around the world
column146: it remains a preventable cause of death in low and middle-\nincome countries (LMIC)
column147: posing a high mortality rate of 10–60% despite treatment [3
column149: low-dose diphtheria toxoid and acellular pertussis vaccine components were\nadded
column150: resulting in the Tdap maternal vaccine offering a triple prevention through one\nimmunization strategy [5
column151: 6].\nThe WHO recommends maternal vaccination against respiratory pathogens
column155: COVID-19 is\nrecommended on a risk-to-benefit basis [11]. The consequences of influenza in pregnancy\nextend beyond maternal health
column156: from increased hospitalization due to cardiorespiratory\ncomplications to increased risk of stillbirth [12–14]. There is little evidence that influenza\ninfects the foetus [15]; however
column157: young infants (<6 months) have high hospitalization rates
column159: and increased mortality [16–18]. While pertussis can\naffect all age groups
column160: pertussis-associated complications are more common among young\ninfants [19
column161: 20]. Infants with pertussis often develop vomiting
column168: infections are easily\ntransmitted from older children
column170: and adults whose milder symptoms may go\nunnoticed [23
column172: COVID-19 during antenatal and perinatal periods\nis associated with increased risk of adverse outcomes
column176: and neonatal SARS-CoV-2 (COVID-19) infection manifested by fever
column179: the WHO and UNICEF recommended a global paradigm shift in the\nimmunization strategy by adopting a life-course approach (LCA) to immunization
column180:
which
involves vaccination programmes tailored to close immunity gaps at different stages of
life. Maternal vaccination plays a pivotal role in this journey [ 26–29]. Maternal COVID-
19 mRNA vaccination rollout and uptake over a relatively short timeframe during the
pandemic could galvanise worldwide momentum and boost acceptance of the safety'
column217:
which occupies a strategic mid-position in the life-course
vaccination spectrum from infancy to older adults [ 30]. Promotion of the interest and
motivation engendered by the pandemic would be an opportunity to increase the adult
vaccination rate globally
column218: including vaccines recommended antenatally [30].\nTo support vaccine uptake
column219: national organizations recommend specific vaccine pro-\ntocols in pregnancy. In Ireland
column220: the National Immunisation Advisory Committee (NIAC)\nof the Royal College of Physicians of Ireland (RCPI) advises the following: one dose of\ninfluenza vaccine at any time in pregnancy [31]
column221: one dose of Tdap vaccine between 16 and\n36 weeks or any time after 36 weeks of pregnancy to maximise neonatal antibody level [32]
column222:
and one course of COVID-19 mRNA vaccination at any point in pregnancy [ 33]. Both
influenza vaccination and Tdap demonstrate no increased risk for adverse maternal or
foetal outcomes [34–37]. However
column226: and\nsafety need continuous monitoring. This was highlighted in 2012 with a resurgence in\npertussis cases globally [ 19]
column227: and Ireland grappled with a 301% increase in cases from\n114 to 458 over a 2-year period [ 38
column228: 39]. Neonatal fatalities underscored the urgency of\nvaccination
column229: with three deaths among unvaccinated infants <2 months of age [38
column231: \nthe 2015/2016 flu season was characterised by a resurgence in the pandemic H1N1 strain
column232: \nand its associated hospitalizations underscored the urgency of maternal immunization [40].\nDespite clear recommendations
column233: maternal vaccination rates in Ireland remain low [38].\nHowever
column234:
the uptake of childhood vaccines included in the National Immunization Pro-
gramme (Supplementary File) is satisfactory despite the recent challenges posed by the
COVID-19 pandemic. Previous studies shed light on factors affecting maternal vaccina-
tion [41]. This scoping review aims to map and summarise factors influencing maternal
vaccination in Ireland
column236: a taxonomy of vac-\ncine determinants: access
column240: and activation [42]. This\nframework focuses on the potential root causes of vaccine coverage gaps
column241: outside of so-\nciodemographic factors. By examining these
column242: we can identify barriers and facilitators\nrelated to maternal vaccination in Ireland
column243: ultimately informing targeted interventions to\nimprove vaccination uptake among pregnant women. This review fills a gap in the existing\nliterature
column244:
offering valuable insights into the specific context of maternal vaccination in
Ireland. Observations from this review would also have a transferable relevance to optimise
maternal immunization in other countries.
2. Methods
2.1. Study Design
This review uses a scoping methodology [ 43
column245: 44]. The process for conducting the\nreview was divided into five stages: identification of the research question; identification of\nrelevant studies; selection of relevant studies; charting the data; and collating
column247:
and reporting the results. The conduct and reporting of results were further guided by the
Preferred Reporting Items for Systematic reviews and Meta-Analyses (PRISMA) Extension
for Scoping Reviews [45].
2.2. Statement of Research Question
This scoping review maps the available literature on maternal vaccination in Ireland
and aims to answer: “What factors contribute to the acceptance or refusal of maternal
vaccination in Ireland?”
2.3. Identification of Relevant Studies
To identify relevant articles
column248: a search of multiple electronic databases was performed\nduring the period March 2023 to May 2023: Embase; EBSCO (Academic Search Complete
column287: and Medline); PubMed; Scopus; Web of Science; and the Irish\nhealth research repository—Lenus. The search strategy utilised a Population–Concept–\nContext (PCC) framework
column288: with the population being pregnant women
column290: and the context being Ireland. The keywords used for the search\nstrategy included terms related to pregnant women
column293:
and
Ireland. The detailed search strategy (Table S1) and an example optimised for PubMed are
described in the Supplementary Materials. Searches were conducted from the inception
of the databases
column295: where search results were limited to 2013\nto 2023 and search terms were restricted (Table S1). An English language limitation was\napplied
column296:
and the reference lists of selected articles were hand-searched to identify additional
relevant studies.
2.4. Selection of Relevant Studies
To enable screening and selection of relevant studies
column297: search results were imported into\nEndnote® citation manager and then exported into Rayyan®
column298: an online screening platform\nfor systematic reviews [46]. After removing duplicates
column299: the screening process involved title\nand abstract screening
column300: followed by a full-text assessment by two independent reviewers\n(AS
column301: SB) applying inclusion and exclusion criteria outlined in Table 1. Where only an\nabstract was available
column302: authors were contacted by email to establish if a full-length article\nwas available. If not
column303: it was excluded. Any discrepancies were resolved through discussion\nwith senior authors (NI
column304:
RKP).
Table 1. Inclusion and exclusion criteria.
Inclusion Criteria Exclusion Criteria
Population: pregnant women or women of reproductive age Studies conducted outside of Ireland.
Concept: factors influencing maternal vaccination Studies focusing solely on non-pregnant women.
Context: Studies conducted in Ireland. Animal studies
column308: freely accessible\narticles. Studies not written in English.\nMethodological approaches: quantitative
column310:
mixed-method studies. Studies with insufficient data or inadequate reporting.
2.5. Charting the Data
Study data was extracted and charted in by two of the authors (AS and SB) using Excel
as follows: title; author; year of publication; study aim/purpose; study design/methodology;
population and sample size; location of study; vaccine type; and factors associated with
uptake/hesitancy . To facilitate the identification and extraction of factors encompassed by
Thomson et al.’s 5A taxonomy (Table S2) [42]
column313: was\nused. Thomson’s 5A framework was used as the coding framework. The definitions of the\n5A dimensions are as follows: ‘access’—the ability of individuals to be reached by
column315: recommended vaccines; ‘affordability’—the ability of individuals to afford vaccination
column316: \nboth in terms of financial and non-financial costs (e.g.
column317: time); ‘awareness’—the degree to\nwhich individuals have knowledge of the need for
column319: recommended vaccines\nand their objective benefits and risks; ‘acceptance’—the degree to which individuals accept
column321: or refuse vaccination; ‘activation’—the degree to which individuals are nudged\ntowards vaccination uptake [42]. Articles were coded to these dimensions. For multinational\nstudies
column322: results relevant/specific to the Irish population were extracted where possible.\n2.6. Collating
column324: and Reporting the Results\nInformation from selected studies was collated and summarised in tables
column325: and re-\nsults of the screening and selection process were summarised using the PRISMA flow\ndiagram [47]. A narrative synthesis was prepared to report the findings. Risk-of-bias'
column361:
557 5 of 15
assessment and quality of evidence of the eligible studies were not envisaged as part of the
scoping review.
3. Results
Searches of nine electronic databases yielded 2458 results
column362: with one article found\nthrough a hand search. Among these
column363: 865 references were sourced from the Irish health\nresearch repository
column365: while 43 were obtained from PubMed. After screening
column366: the\nauthors of four conference abstracts that were not found as full texts were contacted and\nconfirmed that one was never published
column367: and another formed part of a study already\nincluded. The final number of articles included in the review was 12 (Figure 1).\nFigure 1. PRISMA flow diagram reporting search results
column369: and exclusion decisions. WOS—Web\nof Science. * EBSCO search of 4 databases: Academic Search Complete
column372:
and
Medline.
3.1. Study Characteristics
Among the twelve studies selected for review
column375: \nand three used mixed methods. There were four cohort studies and two cross-sectional\nstudies. Two studies were connected
column376: as the sampled participants were from the same\ncohort. Participants in the studies included pregnant women (6/12—50% of studies)
column379: and one study linked to the congenital anomaly register.'
column415: 557 6 of 15\nParticipants were recruited at maternity hospitals in 25% of studies
column416: antenatal clinics associ-\nated with maternity hospitals (17%)
column418: and from the general community\nvia online and in-person market research approaches (25%). Six studies (50%) examined\nboth influenza and pertussis vaccination
column421: and two studies on willingness to receive the COVID-19\nvaccine. Studies were distributed nationally
column423: one national\nstudy covering the Republic of Ireland
column424: one reported from Northern Ireland in the Belfast\nregion
column425: and two international comparative studies (one covering 6 European countries and\nthe other analysing data from 24
column426: including Ireland) (Tables S3 and S4).\n3.2. Sociodemographic Characteristics Associated with Maternal Vaccination\nOverall
column427:
the reported vaccination uptake rates in pregnant or post-partum women
ranged from 40 to 55.1% for influenza and 31 to 67% for Tdap vaccination [48–50]. Sociode-
mographic characteristics statistically associated with vaccine uptake were maternal age
>30 [48
column430: 54]. Higher educational attainment\nwas associated with better influenza vaccination in pregnancy [48]. One study reported\nvaccination was more common in those identifying as Irish descent
column431: while those women\noriginally from Eastern Europe
column433: and Asia/Middle East were less likely to be vac-\ncinated [51]. During the 2017/18 Influenza season in Ireland
column434: 241 pregnant women were\nenrolled in a cross-sectional survey
column435: yielding an influenza and pertussis vaccine uptake of\n61.7% and 49.9%
column436: respectively [54].\n3.3. The 5A Factors Associated with Maternal Vaccination\nApplying Thomson’s 5A taxonomy
column437: the proportion of studies reporting factors associated\nwith maternal vaccination uptake or hesitancy in the 5A dimensions were: 10/12 (83%) ac-\nceptance
column441:
and 3/12 (25%)
activation (Table S4).
3.4. Acceptance
3.4.1. Individual Characteristics
Individual characteristics associated with maternal vaccination were pregnancy status
column444: antenatal vaccination uptake (excluding tetanus toxoid\non a global scale) remained suboptimal [54]. Those more likely to report being vaccinated or\nwilling to receive a vaccine were in their first pregnancy (primigravida)
column450: \nunplanned pregnancy was associated with reduced uptake of the influenza vaccine [51]. In\ngeneral
column451: women conveyed trust in their HCP
column456:
a
qualitative study demonstrated that a lack of consistency in care providers made it difficult
to build trust [57]. The same study revealed a bias towards medication avoidance during
pregnancy extending to immunizations as well [57]. This latter view was also held by some
GPs in a study conducted in the West of Ireland [49].
3.4.2. Perception of Illness
One quantitative study showed that a higher proportion of pregnant women perceived
that pertussis or influenza infection would be more dangerous for the infant than them-
selves [56]. Another study of COVID-19 vaccine uptake showed 5278/6661 (86%) of pregnant
women believed severe COVID-19 during pregnancy could affect foetal development [55].
This concern for the safety of the infant was paramount and also arose in qualitative find-
ings [52
column457: 57]. Another study demonstrated most women (157/198—79%) agreed they were\nmore vulnerable to illness during pregnancy than when not pregnant [ 48]. Among the\nsurveyed HCPs
column458: 883/1180 (74.8%) agreed that influenza in pregnancy increased the risk of'
column495: only 615/1180 (52.1%) identified that it could lead to preterm\ndelivery
column497:
and foetal death [48].
3.4.3. Social Context of HCPs
HCPs’ influence was a key determinant of maternal immunization uptake in multiple
studies [50
column500: 56–58]. A recommendation from a GP was the most common reason for\nvaccine uptake in two studies [48
column503:
inadequate information from HCPs
was the most common reason for non-uptake [50]. Qualitative studies revealed a lack of
consistency in how regularly or intently HCPs discussed and recommended vaccination.
Some vaccinated women highlighted HCPs’ lack of engagement and multidisciplinary coor-
dination [54
column504: 58] and the need for more vaccine-related discussion during appointments [57].\nSome unvaccinated women reported they were neither offered a vaccine nor discussed its\nmerits or safety with any HCP but would accept the vaccine if recommended [ 51
column506: 58].\nOthers perceived the vaccine was not important in pregnancy
column507: if not endorsed by HCPs [57].\nIn one quantitative study
column508:
54/113 (48%) of HCPs answered they never discussed pertussis
vaccination with pregnant patients [50].
Limited peer influence was observed in the reviewed studies. Friends and family were
considered sources of information [50
column510:
their influence was not considered a
major factor in decision making [58]. Social and family responsibility coupled with ‘uptake
conflict’ was represented in pregnant women’s priority to protect the infant from perceived
adverse effects [48
column512: 57]. One study noted that protection of infants from influenza was\nthe most common reason for uptake [48]. Pregnant women felt it was more important to\nprotect the baby than themselves
column513: but did not understand vaccination as a means to protect\nthe infant via passive immunization [57]. In parallel
column514: GPs more than other HCPs felt it was\ntheir responsibility and role to recommend (101/109—92.9%) and offer (100/109—91.7%)\nthe vaccine [48]
column515:
and female HCPs were more likely to do so [49].
3.4.4. Vaccine
Concern about vaccine safety was a common reason for HCPs choosing not to rec-
ommend vaccination [48–50
column518:
81% of GPs who did not recommend
pertussis vaccination had safety concerns versus 29% of recommending GPs [49]. HCPs’
safety concerns predominantly related to insufficient data in pregnancy and the potential
for future complications [49]. Maternal concern about vaccine-mediated harm to the foe-
tus was paramount and associated with reduced uptake [48
column519: 52]. Two qualitative studies\nrevealed that concerns about vaccine safety derived from a perceived risk of vaccination\nand development of long-term conditions (narcolepsy and autism)
column523:
knowing a vaccine was safe was associated with uptake
or uptake intent [50].
Negative perceived efficacy arose as a factor in one qualitative study where pregnant
women reported that they knew someone who received the flu vaccine but also developed
flu [54]. However
column524: women who had received a vaccine in a previous pregnancy or had\nbeen vaccinated for influenza were more likely to be vaccinated for pertussis
column526:
58].
3.5. Affordability
No studies explicitly examined the relationship between vaccine affordability in Ire-
land and vaccine uptake. However
column527:
four studies observed that maternal vaccination uptake
was influenced by public or private funding of antenatal care. Women receiving publicly
funded care were less likely to receive or express intent to accept vaccination compared to
women receiving privately funded care [48
column529: \npublic policy on funding of vaccination during pregnancy differed between countries [59].'
column567: there is no patient-level cost for vaccinations included in the national\nimmunization schedule
column568: although previously an administration fee was applied [ 49
column569:
60].
Fewer than 20% of GPs felt women were declining the pertussis vaccine due to financial
cost [49]. Following a national vaccine funding policy change triggered by a pertussis
outbreak
column570: vaccine administration fees were removed in an effort to increase uptake [54
column571: 61].\nOne qualitative study reported lack of time
column573:
and obtaining
childcare as barriers to vaccination [57].
3.6. Access
3.6.1. Convenience
GPs were reported as most commonly administering vaccines
column574: and women praised\nvaccine availability at community GP visits [ 48
column581: a qualitative study revealed that some women felt having to attend\na GP specifically for vaccination was inconvenient
column582:
and vaccines could be administered by
midwives during antenatal appointments [57]. A quantitative study of HCPs’ attitudes to
vaccination revealed that the majority of pharmacists and hospital doctors were of the view
that vaccination should be administered in any location [ 48]. A contemporary study of
pregnant women indicated that antenatal pertussis vaccine was not discussed sufficiently
in the hospital environment [58].
3.6.2. Location of Vaccination
One study noted differences in uptake of maternal vaccination according to location
column583:
with pregnant women living in the western (Connacht) or northern (Ulster) provinces
less likely to be vaccinated than those in the east (Leinster) [54]. The same study showed
a greater uptake of influenza vaccine in rural areas
column584:
but an inverted relationship with
pertussis vaccination [54].
3.6.3. Contact with Healthcare Systems
Two pregnancy-related factors
column585: unplanned pregnancy and late booking (gestational\nstage >20 weeks at the first booking visit with antenatal care)
column586: were associated with reduced\nlikelihood of being vaccinated for influenza [51]. These factors may be viewed as reasons\nand evidence for less contact with the health system during the course of pregnancy
column587: and\npossibly less opportunity to access information on vaccination. However
column588:
being in the later
stages of gestation (>20 weeks) was also associated with increased willingness to receive
the COVID-19 vaccine [62].
3.7. Awareness
Factors relating to the degree of awareness and knowledge individuals have of vacci-
nation were identified in multiple studies and are categorised by the pregnant women’s or
HCPs’ awareness/knowledge.
3.7.1. Women’s Knowledge of Vaccines and Vaccine Schedule
Three studies examined pregnant women’s awareness and knowledge of vaccina-
tion [50
column590: 58]. Two identified most pregnant women were aware of vaccination
column593: a qualitative study revealed\nthat 7/17 post-partum women had not heard of antenatal pertussis vaccination [ 58]. In\nanother study
column594: over half the participants were unsure if there were risks associated with\ninfluenza vaccination in pregnancy [ 58]. In contrast
column595: a quantitative study revealed that\npregnant women’s knowledge of either influenza or pertussis vaccine safety in pregnancy\nwas associated with better uptake [50].'
column631: 557 9 of 15\n3.7.2. HCPs’ Knowledge of Vaccines and Vaccine Schedule\nThree studies examined HCPs’ awareness and knowledge of vaccination in pregnancy
column632:
re-
vealing high overall awareness but varying levels of knowledge on specific guidelines [48–50].
One single site study of non-consultant hospital doctors (NCHDs) and midwives found 95%
were aware of the national recommendations for influenza and pertussis vaccination during
pregnancy [50]. One national online survey
column635: but only 75.6% knew about pertussis vaccine\nrecommendation [48]. Furthermore
column637: the majority lacked specific\nknowledge of the schedule for pertussis vaccination
column638:
specifically its reduced effectiveness if
given in the last weeks of pregnancy and its recommendation for unvaccinated women within
one week of birth [50].
3.7.3. Availability of Information
GPs were the most common sources of information and considered reliable
column643: and healthcare settings in general\nwere also common sources of information [ 48
column646:
56–58]. Information was provided
in the form of discussions and also through public health information leaflets [ 54]. A
qualitative study identified that women felt leaflets in the absence of discussion were not
helpful [57]. Outside of healthcare settings
column647: information was obtained through friends and\nfamily
column654: and pregnant women compared\ninformation from different sources with the public health information [26]. With respect to\nCOVID-19 vaccination
column656:
but there were also
differences in the interpretation of data [52].
3.8. Activation
3.8.1. Prompts and Reminders
One study noted that during a pertussis outbreak
column657: letters were sent to GPs and public\nhealth nurses
column658: possibly mediating the observed increase in vaccination [ 54]. Crucially
column659: \nstructured educational programmes and support for HCPs were recommended to address\nHCP vaccine confidence and hesitancy to recommend
column660: and to enable effective communica-\ntion with patients for shared decision making [48–50
column663: 56]. To initiate a direct vaccine\nactivation of pregnant women
column664: GPs recommend that a pertussis vaccination reminder be\nincluded in maternity notes and antenatal information packs [49
column665:
56].
3.8.2. Workplace Policies
Vaccination for influenza and pertussis is recommended for HCPs working with infants
in Ireland and should be offered by employers [63]. HCP uptake of vaccines was examined
in two studies. Both revealed that many HCPs still chose not to be vaccinated [48
column666: 50]. The\nmajority (76%) of NCHDs and midwives had not been vaccinated against seasonal influenza at\nthe time of study and did not intend to receive it [50]. In contrast
column667: in an online survey of HCPs\n(432 GPs
column670:
only a minority (267/878—30.4%)
had not received the vaccine [48].
4. Discussion
This scoping review reaffirms the primacy of pregnant women’s sense of responsibility
and intent to protect their unborn infant
column671: and the positive influence of HCPs as the major\ninfluencing factor in maternal vaccination uptake. HCP recommendations are positively\nassociated with uptake
column672: but their delivery—in terms of frequency and sufficiency of in-\nformation provided—is lacking. Effective communication of vaccine risks and benefits is\nhampered
column673: complicating pregnant women’s decision to be vaccinated due to unassuaged'
column709:
557 10 of 15
concerns for vaccine safety for herself and even more for the unborn infant. The reticence
of some healthcare providers to recommend vaccination is attributed to concerns about
potential vaccine adverse effects and is exacerbated by a lack of support from the hierarchy.
This remains a formidable hurdle. Pregnant women seek sources of information outside
of healthcare settings to inform their decisions
column710: indicating a wider potential sphere of\ninfluence
column711: and public awareness campaigns have proved effective
column712:
overcoming established
sociodemographic barriers to vaccination acceptance in Ireland. This is particularly rel-
evant in the post-COVID-19 era by countering misinformation in a timely and effective
manner
column713: cultivating a culture of antenatal vaccine acceptance through targeted antenatal\neducation of women and HCPs
column714: and ensuring equitable access through interdisciplinary\ncoordination [26
column715: 30].\nHealthcare professionals wield substantial social influence in shaping vaccine confi-\ndence among pregnant women
column716: as identified in a recent meta-analysis [ 64]. However
column717:
a
divergence of views within the healthcare community regarding vaccine safety highlights
the need for comprehensive safety data to bolster providers’ confidence. To the authors’
knowledge
column718: there is no routine monitoring of pregnancy-specific vaccine safety indicators
column719: \nand a robust system for the timely dissemination of the collated information to the HCPs\ninvolved in maternal immunization in Ireland
column720: thus hampering HCPs decisions to rec-\nommend and also leaving them ill-equipped to answer questions on vaccine safety from\npregnant mothers
column721: compounding maternal vaccine hesitancy.\nIn the reviewed studies
column722: neither access nor affordability arose as notable barriers\nto maternal immunization in an Irish context
column723: while vaccination programmes among\nsub-populations in some European regions were reported to be negatively influenced by\npatient-level and provider-level affordability concerns [65]. However
column724: in the majority of the\nincluded studies
column725: pregnant or post-partum women were recruited at sites of access
column729: and so this was unlikely to be a\nbarrier for these participants. Expanding access by widening who can provide vaccines
column731: has been shown to increase uptake [66–68].\nQuestions around accessibility
column736: and availability of staff certified to administer vaccines as\nchallenges to access [69
column737: 70]. Affordability was not an issue due to free provision under\nIrish policy; however
column738: it is unclear why privately funded obstetric care is associated with\nbetter pregnancy-specific vaccine uptake compared to publicly funded obstetric care. This\nassociation is found in studies from the US
column741: as recently reviewed\nby Geoghegan et al. [52]. In the US
column742: this is thought to be due
column745: HCP decisions according to insurance coverage
column746:
and HCP-perceived ability
to pay [71].
A significant gap was observed in provider training and support that is intensifying
vaccine hesitancy among pregnant women. For women
column747:
this combination of shortfalls
may create an omission bias where women choose no action rather than a potential yet
improbable harm to their infant [42]. Similar factors were identified in a scoping review
by MacDougall et al. [ 72]. Future research should establish the informational needs of
pregnant women and complementary HCP training. Increasing knowledge and awareness
of the importance of maternal vaccination and its efficacy are important strategies for
increasing vaccination coverage [26

column795: in a meaningful way that addresses identified barriers [75
column798: and HCPs have to collectively educate pregnant women about the\neffectiveness and safety of maternal vaccines and encourage vaccination when the benefits\noutweigh the risks [77]. Consistent and evidence-enabled recommendations from HCPs

column800:
would foster the acceptance of vaccination in pregnancy as an essential component of
antenatal care. Global experience and lessons learned from the rollout of the COVID-19

and future approaches to optimise maternal vaccination strategies [30
column801: 78].\n5. Limitations\nThomson’s 5A taxonomy is based on factors supported by evidential statements
column802: and\nwe conducted this scoping review in a similar manner
column803: examining each study for factors\ninfluencing or related to the maternal vaccine coverage landscape in Ireland. However
column804: \ndue to the limited number of quantitative studies and study designs
column806: while often supported by qualitative findings
column807: do not represent statistical\nassociations with vaccine uptake. Additionally
column809: no critical\nappraisal of the literature was conducted to determine the rigour and validity of the\nfindings
column810: and no risk-of-bias analysis and quality of evidence assessments were performed\nas part of this scoping review. Therefore
column811: care is recommended when deciding which factors\nto target in future intervention designs to optimise the antenatal vaccination rates as an\nintegral part of a life-course preventative approach [26
column815: illuminates the intricate web of factors that\nshape maternal vaccination uptake in Ireland. From knowledge gaps to healthcare provider\nperspectives
column818:
the narrative encompasses a
diverse range of determinants that are likely responsible for the low maternal vaccination
rates observed. Potential effective strategies for improving antenatal vaccination uptake are
consistent and sustained recommendations by HCPs
column819: including reminders in antenatal care\npacks and targeted public awareness campaigns
column820: along with optimal utilization of social\nmedia. By addressing the identified barriers and harnessing facilitators
column821: a roadmap can be\ncharted towards a landscape where maternal vaccination is embraced as a critical part of a\nlife-course immunization strategy
column822:
fostering the well-being of both mothers and infants. It
is paramount to recognize that national immunization programmes need realignment and
redesign with inter-stakeholder and inter-agency participation to ensure comprehensive
protection for individuals across the lifespan. By adopting a life-course approach to immu-
nization
column823: with maternal vaccination as the pivotal central point
column824:
vaccination programmes
could close immunity gaps at various life stages.
